Graphical abstract Carbon-supported Ru catalyst with alkali promoter is arguably the most significant advancement in ammonia synthesis. However, the insufficient stability of this type of catalysts greatly limits their applications, and carbon methanation is often considered as the reason for deactivation. Here we report that there is no clear correlation between carbon methanation and the loss of activity. Rather, carbon oxidation at high temperature, especially via the formation of carbon monoxide, was found to have a strong influence on the activity and stability of Ru catalysts. As a result, there is a significant increase in carbon loss, leading to the sintering of Ru particles and thereby altered hydrogen adsorption. Consequently, catalytic activity and stability of Ru/C catalysts are reduced. This finding contributes to the development of strategies to design carbon-supported metal catalysts with high activity and stability. Keywords Deactivation Carbon-supported Ru catalyst Potassium Ammonia synthesis 1 Introduction Carbon materials have been widely used in heterogeneous catalysis either as catalyst supports or directly as catalysts [1–3]. Increased attention has been paid to the utilization of carbon in the catalysis field with the development of new carbon materials such as carbon nano tubes (CNTs), nanofibers, graphene, fullerenes, nanodiamonds and the ordered mesoporous carbon materials. However, poor stability and lack of understanding of carbon materials’ properties on the catalytic performances are the major obstacles to the wide application of these new carbon materials in heterogeneous catalysis, and only a few types of carbons have been successfully applied as catalyst supports or directly as catalysts for industrial application. The ammonia synthesis is the most important invention of the twentieth century [4]. The application of Ru catalyst supported on high surface area graphite promoted with alkali metal in ammonia plant is argubly the most significant advancement following the work of Haber and Bosch [5]. However, the industrial application of carbon-supported ruthenium catalysts for ammonia synthesis is very limited due to poor stability. The methanation of carbon is suggested to be a major deactivation reason because ruthenium metals have high catalytic activities in hydrogenation of carbons [6,7]. Several strategies, which focused on decreasing the methanation of carbon, have been applied to improve the stability of carbon-supported ruthenium catalysts in the presence of hydrogen. The graphitization of carbon has been reported as one of the widely used strategies for the preparation of carbon-supported Ru catalysts with high stability [5,8–12]. Forni et al. [9,13,14] found the onset temperature of methane formation increased significantly with the increase of the graphitization temperature of carbon for Ru/C catalyst. Brown et al. [5] reported that BP had successfully prepared high surface area graphitic carbon from a natural carbon. Ru catalyst supported on the as-prepared carbon was stable against methanation of carbon and therefore can be used in ammonia plant. The rational use of promoters is also helpful to improve the stability of carbon-supported metal catalysts [15–18]. Kowalczyk et al. [15] found that K promoter and Ru metal could increase the methanation reaction rates, while the presence of barium inhibited the formation of methane for Ru/C catalysts. Rossetti et al. [16] also confirmed that promoters (Ba, Cs or K) and their loading had a strong impact on the starting temperature of methane formation. The simultaneous application of carbon graphitization and rational usage of promoters can further enhance the stability of carbon-supported ruthenium catalyst. The use of these strategies could decrease the amount of the formed methane, but the stability of Ru/C catalysts is still far below what is required for the industrial application. Therefore, it is critical to provide understanding of the underlying deactivation mechanisms of Ru/C catalysts in order to develop strategies to improve carbon-supported ruthenium catalyst activity and stability for its industrial applications. It is well known that a large amount of oxygen-containing functional groups exist in carbon material [19]. Moreover, the addition of Ru metal and promoters would also introduce oxygen sources. Our previous work [20] reported that the formation of CO was unavoidable for carbon-supported Ru catalysts with potassium promoter at above 500°C. Not only carbon methanation, but also carbon oxidation to form carbon monoxide or carbon dioxide could lead to the carbon loss [21,22]. Consequently, besides carbon methanation, carbon oxidation would significantly affect the performances of Ru/C catalysts, which may be another critical issue for the deactivation of carbon-supported Ru catalysts for ammonia synthesis. In this work, K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C catalysts were prepared. The physicochemical properties of Ru catalysts before and after reaction were characterized. The relationship between the catalyst performances and the deactivation mechanism of Ru catalysts was systematically investigated. We believe that our study not only will provide direction to improve the Ru/C catalyst stability, but also will be useful for the design of other carbon-supported metal catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The high surface area and partially graphitic carbon was prepared according to the following procedures [12,23]: commercial activated carbon (1035m2/g, Shanghai Carbon Ltd.) was heated in nitrogen at 1950°C for 2h, and then oxidized in steam at 430°C for 30h. The surface area and total pore volume of the as-obtained carbon were 854m2/g and 0.5cm3/g, respectively. Ru (0.10g Ru metal per gram of carbon) was introduced into carbon (32–60mesh) by incipient wetness impregnation with RuCl3 solution. The as-obtained samples were reduced in hydrogen at 450°C for 6h. Finally, K or Ba promoter was introduced by the impregnation method using Ba(NO3)2 and KOH as promoter precursor, the theoretical weight ratio of promoter to carbon was 9wt.% and 12wt.% for Ba and K promoter, respectively. The catalysts were named as K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out using a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 microscope. X-ray phototoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250 photoelectron spectroscopy with monochromatized Al Ka X-rays (1486.6eV). Thermogravimetric curves (TG) were obtained using a Seteram Setsys Evolution Thermomechanical Analyser. The measurements were carried out in 2.5%N2–7.5%H2–90%Ar gas mixture or argon with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Raman spectra of the samples were obtained from an InVia Reflex Raman microscope equipped with a 532nm laser. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR), Temperature-programmed desorption of hydrogen (H2-TPD) and Temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) studies were carried out in a Micromeritics AutoChem 2920 instrument with mass spectrometry (Hiden Analytical HPR-20). For TPR, the catalyst (100mg, sieve fraction 0.30–0.56mm) was heated with a rate of 10°C/min in a flow of 10% H2/Ar mixture (30mLmin−1). For H2-TPD, the catalyst (100 mg) was reduced in hydrogen at 430°C for 2h, flushed in Ar at 430°C for 1h and then cooled down to 400°C. The sample adsorbed hydrogen at 400°C for 1h and then cooled down to 50°C. After flushed with Ar for 1h, the catalyst was heated up to 900°C at 10°Cmin−1 and then held at 900°C for 30min. For TPSR, the reduced catalyst (100 mg) was heated up to 900°C at 10°Cmin−1 in flowing of 2.5%N2–7.5%H2–90%Ar gas mixture, the signals were recorded by a mass spectrometry (Hiden Analytical HPR-20), where the signals of m/z =2 (H2), 15 (CH4), 28 (CO), 44 (CO2) were monitored. 2.3 Activity measurements Ammonia synthesis activity was measured in a stainless steel reactor with the type-K thermocouples. The catalysts (0.30g, 32–60 meshes, diluted with quartz powder in a 1:30 volumetric ratio) were reduced in the mixture gas (H2/N2 =3.0v/v) at different temperatures (200, 300, 400 and 430°C) and held for 2h at each temperature. Under steady-state conditions of pressure (10MPa), temperature (400°C) and gas flow rate (70dm3 gcat −1 h−1), the ammonia concentration in the gas flow after the reactor was calculated based on a known amount of diluted H2SO4 solution (0.015molL−1), and then the ammonia synthesis rate was measured. The detail calculation equations can be found in our previous paper [20]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Ammonia synthesis activity Fig. 1 shows the ammonia synthesis rates as a function of time on stream. The catalytic activities initially increased with time on steam until a plateau was reached for K-Ru/C catalysts. Whereas the ammonia synthesis rates of the Ba-K-Ru/C catalyst decreased slightly with time on stream. Since the treatment of the catalysts under severe condition is helpful for estimating the stability of carbon-supported Ru catalysts, a high temperature treatment process at 500°C for 40h was carried out. As shown in Fig. 1, the high temperature treatment led to the significantly decrease in the ammonia synthesis rates for Ru catalysts. The activities decreased by about 37% and 29% for K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C, respectively. The surface areas of the fresh K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C catalysts were 468 and 341m2/g, respectively. The surface areas of the spent catalysts slightly decreased to 443 and 305m2/g for K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C, respectively. This result suggests that the significant differences in the catalytic performances are not likely due to the change in carbon surface area change between the fresh and spent catalysts. 3.2 TEM study No distinct diffraction reflections corresponding to potassium, barium or ruthenium compounds were observed in the XRD patterns of the fresh catalysts (Fig. S1), which may be due to the high dispersion of these species on carbon support. The reflections of Ru metal could be observed in the spent catalysts, indicating the increased Ru particle size for the spent samples. This result is in line with TEM study. Ruthenium particles were well dispersed on carbon for the fresh Ru catalysts (Fig. 2 ), and most ruthenium particles were in the range from 1 to 3nm. The average size of Ru particles were estimated to be 1.7nm and 1.8nm for K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C, respectively. Spherical Ru metal particles can be identified for all the spent catalysts (Fig. 3 ) with their lattice fringe of 0.21nm, corresponding to Ru(101) lattice planes [24]. Ru particles were sintered significantly for the spent catalysts, and the mean particle size of Ru in the spent K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C samples were 5.9nm and 4.9nm, respectively. No feature bands corresponding to typical Ru carbonyls or CO chemisorbed on Ru metal were observed [25,26] in the DRIFT spectra of the fresh and spent K-Ru/C (Fig. S2), indicating that the sintering of Ru particles is not likely due to the formation of Ru carbonyls. 3.3 H2-TPD study Reactants and products undergo various steps over catalyst, including diffusion and adsorption of the reactants to the catalyst sites, surface reactions, desorption and diffusion of products from active sites [27]. The adsorption and transition-state energies of intermediates in ammonia synthesis process would scale with each other [28], and thus the adsorption properties of reactant gases may play an important role in catalytic reactions. Nitrogen dissociation was recognized as the rate limiting step for ammonia synthesis over Ru catalysts [29–31], but strong hydrogen adsorption has been found to be the unique feature of ammonia synthesis for Ru catalysts [29,32–34]. Nitrogen chemisorption study on fresh Ru catalysts (data not shown) showed that little nitrogen adsorption could be detected for all samples, which may be due to the fact that most active sites for nitrogen adsorption have been taken up by the adsorbed hydrogen (Figs. 4 and S3). Fig. 4 gives the H2-TPD profiles of the fresh Ru catalysts. In the temperature range of 50–900°C, the desorbed hydrogen may be assigned to three different H species: desorbing below 220°C (Hα), desorbing between 220°C and 510°C (Hβ), and desorbing afterwards (Hγ). The H2-TPD profiles of K-Ru/C (Fig. S3) obtained from the adsorption of hydrogen and a 2.5%N2–7.5%H2–90%Ar gas mixture suggested that the presence of nitrogen strongly affected the amount of hydrogen desorbed at low temperature, especially between 220°C and 510 °C. Furthermore, most hydrogen, which desorbed at low temperature, could be removed by a nitrogen purge at 400°C following hydrogen adsorption. These results indicate that the active sites, on which hydrogen desorbs at low temperature, especially in the range of 220–510°C, are responsible for the reaction of ammonia synthesis. The Hγ species do not desorb at the reaction temperature of ammonia synthesis (∼400°C), and thus these hydrogen species have too strong adsorption and are not likely involved in ammonia synthesis. As shown in Fig. 4 and Table 1 , the presence of K promoter not only significantly increased the amount of three different chemisorbed H species, but also shifted the desorption peak to a lower temperature for Hβ and Hγ. This suggests that K promoter could enhance ammonia synthesis activity of Ru catalysts by changing the chemisorptive properties of hydrogen, more than just as the electron donor to promote N2 dissociation [23,35]. The copresence of Ba and K promoters further increased the amount of hydrogen species desorbed in the temperature range of 50–510 °C compared to that of K-Ru/C, indicating that a synergy effect existed on Ba-K-Ru/C, which is in good agreement with previous results [16,36]. As shown in the H2-TPD profiles of the spent Ru catalysts (Fig. 5 and Table 1), the H species desorbed in the temperature range of 50–515°C (Hα and Hβ) were hardly detected for the spent K-Ru/C catalyst, and the amount of Hγ species also decreased. The amount of desorbed Hα and Hβ species of the spent Ba-K-Ru/C decreased compared to those of the fresh Ba-K-Ru/C catalyst, but the Hγ content for the spent Ba-K-Ru/C sample increased significantly. The effects of these different hydrogen species on the ammonia synthesis activity are needed to be further studied. But the preliminary H2-TPD studies have clearly showed that the low-temperature hydrogen species, especially Hβ species had a strong influence on ammonia synthesis, and thus the catalytic activities of Ba-K-Ru/C were higher than those of K-Ru/C (Fig. 1). The amount of Hβ species of the spent Ba-K-Ru/C was still high, and thus the spent Ba-K-Ru/C showed high catalytic activity. 3.4 Raman study As mentioned earlier, spent catalysts, primarily due to the high temperature treatment at 500°C, had significantly increased Ru particle size. H2 adsorption performances and the catalytic activities of Ru catalysts changed accordingly. Raman spectroscopy is an ideal technique in the structural characterization of carbon materials [37–39] and was used to characterize both fresh and spent catalysts as well as the carbon support. As shown in Fig. 6 , a small shoulder peak at around 1606cm−1 (D′ band) can be found for all samples, indicating the presence of some disordered structure on carbon support. Two pronounced bands centered around 1340cm−1 (D band) and 1580cm−1 (G band) are the main features of the carbon support for all Ru catalysts, and the relative intensity ratio between the D band and G band (I D/I G) was also calculated (see Table 2 ). The I D/I G value of carbon support was 1.94, the value of the fresh K-Ru/C catalyst decreased to 1.58, and further decreased to 1.30 for the spent catalysts with just potassium promoter. The I D/I G values of the fresh and the spent Ba-K-Ru/C were 1.84 and 1.70, respectively, which are much higher than K-Ru/C catalyst. These results suggest that some amorphous carbon may have lost in the spent catalysts. The variation range of I D/I G value between the fresh catalyst and the spent sample for Ba-K-Ru/C was smaller than that for K-Ru/C, indicating that the smaller change in carbon support for Ba-K-Ru/C led to the higher activity and stability. Therefore, it is clear that the carbon loss may have a strong influence on the sintering of Ru particles and catalytic performances for carbon-supported Ru catalysts. 3.5 Studies of carbon loss mechanism Carbon loss may paly a role in affecting catalytic activities and Ru particle sizes for K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C catalysts. Ar-TPD studies of AC, Ru/C, K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C showed that some carbon could be gasified to form CO and CO2 in Ar gas (Figs. S4, 7 and 8 and Table S1). Without K and Ba promoters, the presence of Ru led to the reduced evolution of CO and shift of CO2 desorption peak to low temperature with significantly increased amount of CO2(Fig. S4). Figs. 7 and 8 show the CH4, CO and CO2 desorption profiles obtained upon heating K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C from 50 to 900°C. By comparing the Ar-TPD results, we found that the amount of the desorbed CO significantly increased after the addition of potassium, which was accompanied by the decreased CO2 evolved. The CO formation temperature was lowered to 200°C for K-Ru/C catalyst. These results suggest that the presence of K promoter leads to the higher oxygen evolved for carbon-supported Ru catalyst, which is in agreeement with the result of Zugic et al. [40,41]. No CO2 formation was found at the temperature lower than 320°C when heating K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C in argon. This may be due to the fact that carboxylic groups, which are responsible for the formation of CO2 at low temperature [42], had been removed during the hydrogen reduction of RuCl3/C sample (Fig. S5). On the other hand, the maximum value of CO2 was reached at about 400 and 450°C for Ba-K-Ru/C and K-Ru/C, respectively. It has been suggested that the presence CO2 in Ru catalysts with K promoter may react with potassium promoter to form potassium carbonate [43], which could strongly enhance the gasification of carbonaceous materials by K2CO3-carbon reaction (K2CO3 +C=3CO+2K) [43–49]. Furthermore, CO2 may also be consumed by gasifying carbon to form CO [50]. Therefore, the amount of the released CO2 increased initially and then decreased with the increase of the temperature, and the amount of CO could increase significantly for Ru catalysts with K promoter at high temperature. In contrast, the presence of H2 during the TPD study led to CH4 evolution at low temperature (Figs. 7 and 8). The onset temperature of methane formation was similar to that of CO obtained from Ar-TPD study, suggesting that similar carbon-containing species would be gasified to form CO or CH4 during heat treatment of carbon-supported Ru catalysts in this temperature range, and the gasification products are dependent on the reaction atmosphere. The amount of CH4 evolution increased significantly when the temperature increased to 400°C during heating K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C in a mixture of H2 and argon. It seems that the formation of methane is a major pathway for carbon loss from Ru catalysts below 500°C. The maximum amount of CH4 occurred at ca. 550°C, and the formation of CH4 would be inhibited at higher temperature. On the other hand, the evolution of CO was found at above 500°C, and the amount of CO was significantly enhanced at high temperatures. These results further confirmed that the formation of CO, CO2 or CH4 by carbon gasification would occur during heat treatment of carbon-supported Ru catalysts, and reaction atmosphere has a strong influence on the types of the production. The weight changes of the samples were recorded by TG measurements in a flow of 2.5%N2–7.5%H2–90%Ar gas mixture. As shown in Fig. 9 , the weight loss can be observed for all samples when the reaction temperature reached up to 100°C. Further increasing the temperature to 500°C, the weight loss increased rapidly and then reached to a steady state for all samples. The weight loss ratios at 500°C were ca. 1.7% and 2.3% for K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C, respectively. However, when the temperature was held at 500°C for 5h, the weight loss ratios increased to 18.3% and 9.7% for K-Ru/C and Ba-K-Ru/C, respectively. The comparison between two TG profiles of K-Ru/C catalyst in Ar and 2.5%N2–7.5%H2–90%Ar gas mixture showed that the weight loss ratios in the temperature range of 50–450 °C were similar (Fig. S6). The weight loss of K-Ru/C catalyst obtained in hydrogen-containing gas was much higher than that treated in Ar at above 450 °C. Thus it can be concluded that the presence of hydrogen enhances carbon loss at about 500°C. The weight loss ratio of K-Ru/C with 5wt.% Ru loding in 2.5%N2–7.5%H2–90%Ar at 500°C for 5h was ca. 15.6% (Fig. S7), not significantly less than that of K-Ru/C with high Ru loading (Fig. 9), indicating that there is no linear correlation between the weight loss ratio and Ru loading. The presence of hydrogen or higher Ru loading promoted carbon gasification, but their effect on carbon loss is much less than that of K promoter and the surface properties of carbon support. TPSR studies of Ru catalysts (Fig. 10 ) showed that the formation rate of CH4 decreased initially and then increased significantly with the increase of temperature. The maximum rate of methane formation was reached at ca. 310°C for all Ru catalysts. Furthermore, the onset temperature of methane formation during TPSR study was much higher than those obtained from TPSR measure. These results may be due to the fact that the presence of nitrogen enhanced the formation of hydrogen atoms, and then the hydrogen atom would react with carbon to form methane at lower temperature. The methane formation rate of Ba-K-Ru/C was higher than that of K-Ru/C promoter at above 310°C. However, when the reaction temperature was further increased, the methane formation rate would gradually decrease, but the formation of methane was still observed during the TPSR study at 500°C for 5h. Furthermore, some carbon was consumed to form CO2 during TPSR study in the temperature range of 50–320°C. The disappearance of CO2 along with the maximum rate of methane formation were observed for all Ru catalysts, and the CO2 content increased with the decrease of methane at higher temperature. These observations suggest that the change in the reaction temperature strongly affects the products of carbon gasification. It should be noted that Kowalczyk et al. [15] found that the presence of K promoter enhanced the activity of carbon methanation for Ru/C catalyst, whereas Ba promoter decreased the reaction rates of carbon methanation. But here we found Ba-K-Ru/C showed higher methanation rates than K-Ru/C. The discrepancy in the promoter effect on carbon methanation may be due to the difference in the reaction condition. Kowalczyk et al. [15] studied the methanation of carbon support in H2, and our TPSR study was studied in the flow of 2.5%N2–7.5%H2–90%Ar gas mixture. Rossetti et al. [16] also found the methanation rates of Ru/C catalysts with co-presence of Ba and K (or Cs) were higher than those of Ba-promoted Ru/C catalyst when they studied the resistance of Ru/C catalyst by increasing the reaction temperature up to 700°C. Although the formation of methane and CO2 at low temperature was observed during the TPSR study, no weight loss was observed during thermogravimetric analysis of K-Ru/C at 400°C for 5h in N2–H2–Ar gas mixture (Fig. S8). But the catalysts with K promoter showed a significant weight loss when the temperature was held at 500°C for 5h (Fig. 9). These results suggest that the high temperature is a key factor for carbon loss and catalyst deactivation. The high-temperature treatment of Ru/C catalysts with K promoter led to the significant carbon loss because the formation of CO was unavoidable for Ru/C catalyst. Therefore, the structure of carbon could be destroyed at higher temperature, which could lead to the sintering of Ru particles, and consequently the reduced number of active sites available for the adsorbed hydrogen at low temperature. Other sites would be taken up by hydrogen atoms, and this type of hydrogen cannot desorbe at the reaction temperature of ammonia synthesis. Therefore, nitrogen cleavage on Ru metal would be inhibited [29,51–53], and the catalytic activities of Ru catalyts decreased greatly. On the other hand, the formation of methane may not be the key factor for the deactivation of Ru catalysts with heat treatment at 500°C. Heat treatment of carbon-supported Ru catalysts in the flow of methane (Fig. S9) showed that methane would be consumed at above 340°C, which was accompanied by the formation of H2, CO and CO2. It is well known that methane can bea carbon source for preparing nanocarbons over Ru catalyst [54]. Therefore, some methane would be consumed to form the deposited carbon, and thus the formation of methane, especially at low temperature, may have a limited influence on the carbon loss and catalyst deavtivation for carbon-supported Ru catalysts. Consequently, all strategies, which could efficiently inhibit the gasification of carbon, may be reasonably applied to prepare carbon-supported Ru catalysts with high activity and stability. For example, some methods, including the graphitization of carbon [5,8–12] and hydrogen treatment of active carbon [55,56], have been found to greatly increase the activity and the stability of Ru/C catalysts. Furthermore, the present investigation clearly showed that K exerted a strong influence on the chemisorptive properties of hydrogen. Therefore, other compounds, which could inhibit carbon gasification without changing the chemisorptive properties of K promoted Ru catalyst, may be a replacement of alkali promoters. One strategy to prepare Ru/C catalysts with high stability is the rational use of other metals to decrease the amount of carbon loss, such as, changing the reaction pathway of carbon gasification [57] or promoting coke formation based on the products of carbon gasification. 4 Conclusions The activity and stability of three carbon-supported ruthenium catalysts with different promoters for ammonia synthesis were investigated. The physicochemical properties of Ru catalysts before and after reaction were characterized. We found that carbon loss, via carbon methanation and carbon oxidation to form carbon dioxide and carbon momoxide, had a strong influence on the ammonia synthesis rates and the stability of Ru/C catalysts. Carbon loss, especially carbon oxidation, resulted in the increase of Ru particle size, and the decrease of active sites available for the desorbed hydrogen at low temperature. As a result, surface of Ru catalysts would be taken up by hydrogen atoms, and the H-dominated surface has a negative influence on ammonia synthesis. Therefore, the catalytic activity and the stability of Ru/C catalysts decreased significantly. Based on these findings, all strategies, which could efficiently inhibit carbon gasification, could be helpful to prepare carbon-supported Ru catalysts with high activity and stability. coredata.dc:description: Carbon-supported Ru catalyst with alkali promoter is arguably the most significant advancement in ammonia synthesis. However, the insufficient stability of this type of catalysts greatly limits their applications, and carbon methanation is often considered as the reason for deactivation. Here we report that there is no clear correlation between carbon methanation and the loss of activity. Rather, carbon oxidation at high temperature, especially via the formation of carbon monoxide, was found to have a strong influence on the activity and stability of Ru catalysts. As a result, there is a significant increase in carbon loss, leading to the sintering of Ru particles and thereby altered hydrogen adsorption. Consequently, catalytic activity and stability of Ru/C catalysts are reduced. This finding contributes to the development of strategies to design carbon-supported metal catalysts with high activity and stability.
coredata.dc:title: Deactivation study of carbon-supported ruthenium catalyst with potassium promoter
